Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Situation2: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Story: My phone buzzed just as I pulled up to the curb for my next fare. It was my sister, her voice trembling, asking if I could come over—she needed to talk, really talk, about something she couldn’t handle alone. I promised her, years ago, that I’d always be there when she needed me. But as I hung up, my passenger slid into the back seat, chatting about the weather and how he had all the time in the world before his meeting. I glanced at the clock, calculating the route. If I took him now, I’d be late getting to my sister. If I canceled, I’d break my promise to the dispatcher about reliability, and maybe lose a regular customer. My hands tightened on the wheel. My sister’s voice echoed in my mind, but so did the unspoken expectation that I’d get this man safely and promptly to his destination. I sat there, torn, the meter ticking, my heart pounding, caught between being the brother she needed and the driver I was supposed to be.
